Serving as the [[Capital city|administrative center]] of the [[Krasnodonskyi Raion]] ([[Raion|district]]), the city itself is also designated as a separate raion within the oblast. The population of Krasnodon in 1972 was 70,400, in 1989 it was around 53,000, in 2001 it was 49,921. {{Ru icon}} {{cite web|url=http://www.ukrcensus.gov.ua/rus/results/general/city/|title=Ð§Ð¸ÑÐ»ÐµÐ½Ð½Ð¾ÑÑÑ Ð¸ ÑÐ¾ÑÑÐ°Ð² Ð½Ð°ÑÐµÐ»ÐµÐ½Ð¸Ñ Ð£ÐºÑÐ°Ð¸Ð½Ñ |publisher=ukrcensus.gov.ua|accessdate=March 19, 2009}} ==History== Krasnodon was established in 1914 along the banks of the Welikyj Kamjaniza, a tributary of the [[Seversky Donets|Seversky Donets River]], as the settlement of '''Sorokino'''. It soon became one of the centers of the [[coal mining]] industry of the [[Donbass]] region. By a ''Decision of the [[Presidium of the Supreme Soviet|Presidium of the Supreme Soviet of the USSR]]'', on October 28, 1938 it was renamed ''Krasnodon''. During the [[German-Soviet War]] Krasnodon was occupied by [[Nazi Germany]] from July 20, 1942 to February 14, 1943. In that period, between October 1942 and January 1943, the [[anti-nazi]] [[Komsomol]] organization [[Young Guard (Soviet resistance)|Young Guard]] operated in the city.
